Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funds to support the running of the 2014 Graduate Student Combinatorics Conference (GSCC) to be held at Auburn University from April 4 to 6, 2014. This will be the 10th annual conference held in this well-established series. The main purpose of this conference is to bring together graduate students in combinatorics with the following goals: to educate participants about the many areas of combinatorics; to share current research topics and open questions; to have participants meet and network with fellow combinatorics graduate students from across the country; and to provide the opportunity to work together on current research. This format also allows for vertical integration in that young graduate students who are just beginning their graduate careers are able to meet and learn from more senior graduate students about their experiences in and approaches to doing research.

This conference is unique in that it is both designed specifically for graduate students, and it is organized and run essentially by the graduate students themselves. Combinatorics faculty at Auburn and the invited speakers will act as mentors for the students through this process. Giving young researchers the opportunity to come together to share their ideas and methods with each other and to learn about different areas of combinatorics is a major theme of this conference. There is a multitude of areas of research in combinatorics, including graph theory of many types, design theory, coding theory, enumeration, and set systems. Many schools have a specific focus and their graduate students are not aware of problems or proof techniques from other areas. This conference is designed to help graduate students appreciate the breadth of combinatorics, with students from many different backgrounds presenting and sharing their results and proof techniques in an informal supportive environment. In so doing, these graduate students are likely to forge professisonal relationships which we expect to extend well into their post-graduate careers, thereby adding to the mix of creative research in subsequent years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 10th Graduate Student Combinatorics Conference (GSCC), this time held at Auburn University, provided the opportunity for young researchers (primarily graduate students) to learn about new areas of mathematics, see connections between different areas of mathematics, and meet fellow researchers with whom they could work on various challenging problems. The NSF grant was extremely beneficial in the running of this conference since it was used to provide travel support; this support was critical in enabling many of the participants to be able to attend the conference.

    ?The first objective of the GSCC was to provide graduate students the opportunity to see research and topics related to but outside their specific discipline. This was done in a variety of ways. First, there were twenty-eight talks given by graduate students on their own research. While the talks were all in combinatorics, they focused on a number of different topics such as design theory, domination in graphs, geometrical graph theory, and set systems. These twenty-eight talks were complemented by four keynote talks, all of which had some relationship to some other area of mathematics, namely geometry (two talks), algebra, and linear programming. The conference also featured an interactive exhibit showing how geometry relates to our everyday lives.

The second objective of the GSCC was to help develop the research activities of the participants, both by providing opportunities for new research to be developed by attendees of the conference, and by creating a network of colleagues at similar stages of their careers that may lead to future research collaboration. One way in which this objective was promoted was through an open problem session held during the conference. In this session, several problems were presented by the participants and discussed by those present, all in the expectation that participants would find mutual interest that would lead to future collaborations. Another opportunity for research was presented by John Conway, who was one of the keynote speakers at the conference. While at the conference, he presented five challenging problems that he would like to see solved.

    Supporting the effort to create a network of young combinatorialists, the conference attracted 43 students or recent graduates, along with 11 faculty who were there to act as resources at the conference. The students came from 16 universities, from states as far afield as California, Texas, Michigan, Kentucky, and Pennsylvania, and as close as Alabama and Georgia.
